trial_identification.studytitle: Doctors Working Well: A Study Evaluating an Online Stress Management Program for Doctors
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A Randomised Controlled Trial of an Online Intervention on Resiliency, Occupational Stress, and Burnout among Junior Medical Doctors

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of normal psychology, cognitive function and behaviour

interventions.interventions:
Doctors Working Well is an online program designed to target occupational stress and burnout. The intervention will consist of 6 online modules (each of approximately 30-45 minutes duration) that focus on stress management techniques, emotion monitoring and regulation techniques, and self-care. Participants will have access to one module per week over a six week period. At the start of each module they will also be asked to answer a small number of questions relating to their mood and engagement with skills learnt in the previous module.
Each module contains a mixture of didactic and interactive learning activities, such as readings, quizzes, videos, and personal reflections. Development of the program was led by a clinical psychologist with six years treatment experience, with input also received from two other research team members, who are both also psychologists. Intervention adherence will not be assessed as the program content will be delivered consistently across participants, due to the electronic format of the intervention. Participant adherence to the intervention will be assessed through examination of number of log ins, time spent using program, modules completed, and activities completed within each module. As a strategy to increase participant adherence, individuals will receive an automated email upon completion of each module, commending effort and completion. Participants will also be sent an automated reminder email if a module hasn't been completed within 2 days of it becoming available on the weekly cycle.
interventions.comparator: An active control condition will be utilized, in which participants will be given one hour per week of protected individual study time, for the six week study period. After completing the three month follow up assessment, those participants allocated to the control condition will then receive access to the online program.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Stress as measured by the stress subscale of the Depression and Anxiety Stress Scales - 21 item version
primaryOutcome.timepoint: pre intervention, post intervention (end of week 6 module), 3 months following intervention

primaryOutcome.outcome: Burnout as measured by the Copenhagen Burnout Inventory
primaryOutcome.timepoint: pre intervention, post intervention (end of week 6 module), 3 months following intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: depression as measured by the depression subscale of the Depression, Anxiety, and Stress Scales - 21 item version
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: pre intervention, post intervention (end of week 6 module), 3 months following intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: anxiety as measured by the anxiety subscale of the Depression, Anxiety, and Stress Scales - 21 item version
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: pre intervention, post intervention (end of week 6 module), 3 months following intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: resilience as measured by the Brief Resilience Scale
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: pre intervention, post intervention (end of week 6 module), 3 months following intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Affect as measured by the Positive and Negative Affect Scales
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: pre intervention, post intervention (end of week 6 module), 3 months following intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: psychological distress as measured by the Kessler-10 scale
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: pre intervention, post intervention (end of week 6 module), 3 months following intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: mindfulness as measured by the Cognitive and Affective Mindfulness Scale - Revised
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: pre intervention, post intervention (end of week 6 module), 3 months following intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: self-care as measured by the six subscales of nutrition/ hydration, exercise, rest, relationships, self-compassion, and general, from the Mindful Self-Care Scale
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: pre intervention, post intervention (end of week 6 module), 3 months following intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: stigma as measured by the Stigma of Occupational Stress Scale for Doctors
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: pre intervention, post intervention (end of week 6 module), 3 months following intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: satisfaction with the program as measured by the Client Satisfaction Questionnaire - 8 item version

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Participants will be registered junior medical doctors (in this study, defined as being an intern, junior house, or senior house doctor) practicing in the West Moreton Hospital and Health Service district (Queensland, Australia), aged 18 years or older.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Aged younger than 18 years, not a medical doctor, or practicing outside the West Moreton Hospital and Health Service area.

trial_design.sequence: individual, sequential, simple randomisation, using a computer generated string
trial_design.statisticalmethods: Multilevel statistical modelling will be used to analyse the data. The multilevel models will be fitted with the MIXED procedure in SPSS and alpha criterion set at .05. As such, data from all randomised participants will be used in analyses. Time (two levels, pre- and post-) will be entered with each outcome variable and the interaction term of each outcome variable x time. A similar set of analyses using multilevel modelling will be conducted to assess maintenance of treatment gains between post and follow up time points.

fundingsource.fundingname: West Moreton Hospital and Health Service

secondarysponsor.sponsorname: West Moreton Hosptial and Health Service

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
Participants will be randomly allocated to either treatment or control conditions. All participants will be asked to complete a number of pre-treatment questionnaires. These questionnaires will measure stress, burnout, resilience, mood, and related factors. Those participants allocated to the treatment condition will then be provided with access to the online intervention. The intervention will consist of 6 online modules (each of approximately 30-45 minutes duration) that focus on stress management techniques, emotion monitoring and regulation techniques, and selfcare.
Participants will have access to one module per week over a six week period. At the start of each module they will also be asked to answer a small number of questions relating to their mood and engagement with skills learnt in the previous module. Participants allocated to the control condition will not be given access to the intervention, but rather, will be given the equivalent amount of time each week as protected study time. At the end of the six week intervention period, and again three months following the intervention, participants will be asked to complete a small number of questionnaires measuring the same constructs as at pre-intervention, with the addition of a small number of questions relating to satisfaction and experience with the program.
